am not sure why there is so much debate about this. It's pretty simple, If your target user base is mobile users and your feature set needs more than the browser can provide, you go native else you go HTML5.
@iggym I definitely agree.  When it comes to what the user sees, I'm a fan of "do it right or don't do it at all."

additionally native apps are not a fad, there's maybe half a billion users with iOS and Android devices so eventually you will need to do native apps if you are serious about mobile. Investing in iOS and Android development at this point is not optional, it is mandatory, because iOS and Android won't disappear soon, so the sooner you invest in this technologies, the better. To be relevant today you will have to develop an iOS app and an Android app because native mobile development is probably as important as the web, maybe even more important as Eric Schmidt says "Mobile first"...

@zoidberg I agree that vendor lock in is bad... :(

One difference is that HTML5 is a standard, so while it's going to be ubiquitous, it can not change very quickly, there are standard committees to go through, browser makers have to implement etc. Instead native platforms are proprietary, so they can change on a whim. Jobs wants a gyro on the thing? Add gyro API, ship, done. Try to do that with HTML5. Since mobile is changing so fast now, the advantage is to the apps, but on the desktop, which is more mature, most things can be done in HTML5. Once smartphones reach a certain degree of maturity my guess is the pendulum will swing again toward the standard solution.
well, the iPhone has a way to make calls in Javascript out to the application container, but then you're back to the issue of having to at least rewrite all those calls for each platform

I agree with piccolbo. In the meanwhile it's fun learning all the CANs and CAN'Ts of each technology.  I rather do programming in HTML5. Here is an example of a demo app for HTML5 (around min 1:15)  http://vimeo.com/19817986

@piccolbo you are right about the problems of standards driven technologies but we can't use that as an excuse any more, we should always strive to deliver the best user experiences that are possible for the moment. Most solutions that we are developing today will have a usable life that is less than one year, so the best strategy is probably a hybrid solution that evolves with the needs of the users.

Honestly the 'write once deploy everywhere' has always been a pipe dream that  rarely works out. If you're a business that's serious about mobile, the investment in writing your app native is trivial. There's consultants and small studios that will gladly be your iOS department for not a whole lot of cash.

I had this conversation [yet again] recently with a colleague. Working on iPhone apps I see the HUGE difference between the result quality. With HTML5 let's talk about the lack of the look, feel and responsiveness, the build size being HUGE compared to native [remember, the UI must be built out mostly with images [some css] so instead of compiling obj-c to make a UITabBar you need to add in a bunch of images/image states etc. Being already compiling vs. run time compilation is a huge issue when you are working on a processor with far less capacity than a desktop. Basically I feel as if HTML5 is a crutch for those that can't. You could argue that building one time [mostly] for several platforms is superior ... but the quality is awful.
size and performance argument is really good.
